column3: One of the ways the factory would cover up and use spoiled meat is through the pickling ham process, the text notes that "to pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor" and if there was still rotten meat then "they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron."  The most extreme way to disguise the spoiled and practically unusable meat was to put it in the sausage, after the spoiled meat was thoroughly chopped up, "it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption."
column4: The factory would find ways to cover up and misuse spoiled meat, one way was through the pickling process. This process involved injecting a second, stronger pickle that overpowered the odor of spoiled meat. If there was still rotten meat, the factory would extract the bone from the meat and insert a hole with a white-hot iron. The most extreme method used was to disguise spoiled meat by adding borax and glycerin to create a paste and stuffing it into sausages before they were processed for home consumption.

column3: Three elements of a tragedy include a character that is neither good nor evil but is relatable to the audience. It also includes an error in the main characters ways which leads them to their demise and they all end in tragic ways such as death. The most important part of a tragedy is that they are relatable to the audience. This is shown in paragraph two when the author says he must be, "that of a man who is not eminently good and just, yet whose misfortune is brought... by some error of judgement or frailty." If the main character is not relatable to the audience then the ending will not have the same effect and the audience's emotions wouldn't be pulled out of them for catharsis.
column4: A tragedy requires a relatable protagonist, a storyline error, and tragic ending. A character must be relatable to the audience, as described in paragraph 2, where the author says that he must be "a man who is not eminently good and just, yet whose misfortune is brought on by some kind of error or frailty." The conclusion also needs to have a strong emotional impact, pulling the audience through an emotional experience. If these elements are absent, the audience's emotional connection to the protagonist is lost, and the tragedy loses its intended purpose.

column3: Meat butchering factories used many different unsanitary and unlawful practices to cover up spoiled meat. Factories used spoiled meat in sausage as the smell wouldnt be affected greatly becuase of the wuantity of meat being ground. Factories used soda to rub away the smell of rot o meats. Factories also filled hams with pickle to make them stop smelling. Factories also extracted the bones and inserted burning hot metal rods into meat to burn away the most rotted parts of the meat. I know this becuase the text says this, " the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell ...  a machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds. And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor...Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as “Number Three Grade,” but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade—there was only Number One Grade. The packers were always originating such schemes"

column3: Some ways the meatpacking industry would use or cover up spoiled meat would be by canning it, chopping it up into a sausage, extracting the bone and inserting white-hot iron, and rubbing the meat with soda to cover up the smell. In addition, an ingenious person presented a new device that " would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade—there was only Number One Grade." column4: The meatpacking industry employed various deceptive practices to cover up and sell spoiled meat. They were ingenious in their methods, resulting in the abolishment of the Number One, Two, and Three Grade system.

column3: Aristole describes the perfect tragedy in three aspects. The first is that a prosperous man faces adversity and sends a shock to the reader. Artisans and merchants, known as merchants, played a crucial role in supplying goods and ensuring that the people had what they needed.

column3: The Third Wave was an experiment that was designed by a history teacher named Ron Jones. He did this to "explain to his students how people throughtout history followed the crowd even when terrible things were happening" as said in paragraph 1. He started reinforcing rules in his class as part of the experiment. He did not tell his students that it was an experiment. He started with only 30 students and after three days he had 43 attendees. By the end of the day he had more than 200 participants. On the fourth day the experiment was getting out of control. Ron told the students that "the Third Wave was a part of a nationwide movement". On the last day they were going to watch their leader on television. In the end, Jones told them it was all part of an experiment.
column4: The Third Wave was a history experiment designed by Ron Jones, a history teacher. The experiment was intended to help students understand how people thought throughout history followed the crowd even when terrible things were happening. Jones started reinforcing rules in his classroom and soon had over 200 participants. However, the experiment started to get out of control, and Jones decided to tell the students that it was a part of a nationwide movement. On the final day, they watched their leader on television to see what was happening. Jones told them that the experiment was part of an experiment and that they should just go with the flow.

column3: History teacher Ron Jones wanted to better explain why in history people blindly followed vrowds and movements. He did this by creating a fake movement that he name "The Third Wave" that encouraged strength through  discipline, pride, community, and action. Under the third wave the kids had to  follow strict rules in and out of the classroom. Over a five day period the movement acrewed over 200 memeber and they had adopted a new salute that Mr Jones had created to look like the Nazi salute. This all ended when Mr. Jones told them through a TV broadcast that it was all an expiriment to show how easily people would follow a group.
column4: History teacher Ron Jones sought to explain the historical phenomenon of crowds and individuals blindly following movements and trends. He achieved this by orchestrating an alternative movement called the Third Wave, encouraging a culture of discipline, pride, community, and action among the students. Under the Third Wave, students were required to follow strict rules and adhere to them strictly within the classroom boundaries. Over the course of five consecutive days, the Third Wave garnered over 200 members. A custom salute was established by Ron Jones to resemble the Nazi salute, which became

column3: The first of three elements of an ideal tragedy follow the type of character used.  Aristotle believes that the character of a tragedy should not be a villain and nor should it be a hero as this creates fundamental flaws within the emotions of the reader which brings me to the second element of an ideal tragedy.  The second element of an ideal tragedy is that the emotions and experiences had by the character must appear relatable to the reader as these are the precise emotions that a tragedy aims to make the reader feel.  By allowing the reader to actually feel tragedy they are left with the emotions of a tragic conclusion which brings me to the final aspect of an ideal tragedy.  The final element of a proper tragedy is that the conclusion must remain tragic; meaning that the character must not see his conditions reverse.  By allowing the character to remain in tragedy even through the end of the story the author allows the reader to bask in the emotions that are ever-present in a successful tragedy.
column4: The first element of an ideal tragedy is the character type, which should not be a villain or a hero. This elements creates fundamental flaws within the reader's emotions and brings them to an emotional connection with the tragedy. The second element of an ideal tragedy is the emotional resonance or relatability of the character's experiences and emotions to the reader. This allows the reader to feel the emotions of a tragic conclusion and escape into a shared experience. The final element of an ideal tragedy is that the conclusion should remain tragic, where the character is unable to reverse their conditions. By leaving the character's circumstances unresolved and allowing the reader to experience tragedy through the end of the story, the author creates an emotional impact that enhances the tragedy's message and evokes a sense of connection.

Below them were the noble and priestly class who served and pleased the gods and held official positions. Meanwhile, the bottom rung of the pyramid was occupied by slaves and farmers who toiled relentlessly to fulfill the desires of the ruling elite.

column3: "The Third Wave", written by the Common Lit Staff, was a story about a history teacher at a high school found himself unable to explain to his students how people throughout history followed the crowd even when terrible things were happening. The wave developed over such a short period by the students getting involved in the experiment to see what Jones was talking about. It states," After only three days, the experiment took on a life of its own, with students from all over the school joining in." This statement is simply saying that the experiment started to take a route that no one really expected, especially Jones. Students from all over started to tell Jones on other members that failed to abide by the rules and the loyalty was outstanding. With this being said, Jones felt it was getting out of control so he decided to terminate the movement. It states in pargraph 4," By the fourth day of the experiment, the students became increasingly involved in the project and their discipline and loyalty to the project was so outstanding that Jones felt it was slipping out of control." The statement explains why Jones felt he had to end the experiment. This short story is explaining how people can get out of control when following a crowd which is what Jones found out and he had to end the experiment.
column4: The Common Lit Staff's "The Third Wave" was a narrative that highlighted the impact of an experiment when students actively participated. It demonstrated how the wave's trajectory deviated from what Jones intended, much like Jones's experiment. Students became increasingly involved, challenging the established norms and showing remarkable loyalty to the project. However, even with the students' best efforts, the wave became uncontrollable, and Jones felt compelled to terminate the experiment.

column3: in the text it says ¨With one member trimming beef in a cannery, and another working in a sausage factory, the family had a first-hand knowledge of the great majority of Packingtown swindles. For it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage. With what had been told them by Jonas, who had worked in the pickle rooms, they could now study the whole of the spoiled-meat industry on the inside, and read a new and grim meaning into that old Packingtown jest—that they use everything of the pig except the squeal.¨
column4: The family possessed firsthand knowledge of the operations of a canning factory and a sausage factory in Packingtown. Through their conversations with Jonas, who had worked in the pickle rooms, they gained valuable insights into the process of spoiling meat and the significance of packaging in the food industry. They discovered the custom of canning spoiled meat, not only for preservation but also for the creative repurposing of the pig's leftovers.

column3: One way the factory would cover up spoiled meat odor was by pickling the hams that were spoiled, and if the meat managed to stink again they would be pickled once more with a stronger solution and sold to the public. In the text it states, "...there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them... the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor—a process known to the workers as “giving them thirty per cent.” The next way the facotry would use spoiled meat was through dosing moldy and white meat from Europe in borax and glycerin so that it could be served to the public. In the passage it states, "...old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white – it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." Then, an invention came about that could allow bad meat to be sold as Grade One meat through inserting a hot white iron in place of the bone. In the passage it states, "...but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron." Lastly, the factory would mix old disgusting meat that had been sitting for months with new meat, borax, and colored gelatin to make it look normal and process it for the public. "Every spring they did it; and in the barrels would be dirt and rust and old nails and stale water – and cartload after cartload of it would be taken up and dumped into the hoppers with fresh meat... Every spring they did it; and in the barrels would be dirt and rust and old nails and stale water – and cartload after cartload of it would be taken up and dumped into the hoppers with fresh meat."
column4: The factory had a creative and ingenious way of dealing with spoiled meat, and they found several ways to reprocess it and get it sold to the public.

column3: The first two elements are pity and fear, inducing them alerts the readers that it is indeed a tragedy. the last one is to have a small part of happiness in the tragedy, giving the audience the feeling that something good may have happened.
column4: The first two elements establish an unsettling atmosphere, hinting that tragedy is imminent. A small amount of happiness amidst the suffering serves to distract the audience from the bleakness of the situation.

column4: Sure, here is a rewritten version:  The structure of the ancient Egyptian government was arranged like a pyramid. The pharaohs, representing the divine, held the highest position in society. Their belief in divine control over the universe dictated that they were placed at the apex of the social ladder. Nobles and priests, who held lower ranks, were responsible for pleasing the gods and maintaining harmony and order within the society.
